Any suggestions/ideas ?

<@U1A6TJ0KV|holocron> has joined the channel
hello, i'm running into a problem building the s390x peer, it seems there's a problem with the apt repo in the dockerhub hyperledger/fabric-baseimage:s390x-0.0.10 image

Step 11 : RUN /hyperledger/scripts/provision/common.sh
 ---> Running in d9da24b3b1f8
E: Failed to fetch <mirror://mirrors.ubuntu.com/mirrors.txt/dists/xenial/main/binary-s390x/by-hash/SHA256/0956d9bdd044570b5d8f1b3e186bb7bddb01b786174329ffa87c9596678defcb>  Hash Sum mismatch
<https://jira.hyperledger.org/browse/FAB-286>
<@U1A6TJ0KV> i have lots of problems with the ubuntu mirror network…the latest master has the mirror stuff disabled
can you try running on the latest?
thats the only thing I can think of
<@U0KPFAZNF> starting with an empty docker image and container list, and immediately after running git pull on the master branch...
so far so good

<@U0KPFAZNF> made it further, but

Status: Downloaded newer image for openjdk:8
 ---> ea40c858f006
Step 2 : RUN wget <https://services.gradle.org/distributions/gradle-2.12-bin.zip> -P /tmp --quiet
 ---> Running in 95a3948a80f8
rpc error: code = 2 desc = "oci runtime error: exec format error"
Makefile:213: recipe for target 'build/image/javaenv/.dummy' failed
make: *** [build/image/javaenv/.dummy] Error 1

<https://gist.github.com/vmorris/82fb51e86a92f5dcbb6e40ec197f0a66>
openjdk:8 is x86 yeah?
looks like the java team needs to re-work that
what we could do is disable java support on Z until that is addressed

Perhaps there is a way to hand edit the Dockerfile for the java image and use the hyperledger/fabric-baseimage in the  FROM statuement and add a RUN statement to install openjdk (which should pull from the s390x repos)
I first ran into this java issue last week.
my impression from the above snippet is the problem is with gradle-..bin
no
the exec format error is usually indicative of running a docker image that was built for another platform.
that's been my experience
I think the problem is in scripts/provision/host.sh

```scripts/provision/host.sh:update-java-alternatives -s java-1.8.0-openjdk-amd64
```
ah, yep
and this applies to ppc64le as well
agreed
this should be more generic to point to the arch specific java dir
i agree
oh, we could just refactor the platform to install jre8+
part of the problem is the base installs default-jre and then the java config adds jre8+alternatives
would it be easier if the entire platform just installed jre8?
(I wouldnt mind this personally, I have code that can take advantage of 8 that I had to disable on account of devenv installing jre7

I already have jre8 installed. ```# dpkg -l | grep jre
ii  default-jre                            2:1.8-56ubuntu2                  ppc64el      Standard Java or Java compatible Runtime
ii  default-jre-headless                   2:1.8-56ubuntu2                  ppc64el      Standard Java or Java compatible Runtime (headless)
ii  openjdk-8-jre:ppc64el                  8u91-b14-3ubuntu1~16.04.1        ppc64el      OpenJDK Java runtime, using Hotspot JIT
ii  openjdk-8-jre-headless:ppc64el         8u91-b14-3ubuntu1~16.04.1        ppc64el      OpenJDK Java runtime, using Hotspot JIT (headless)
```
still see the same issue
i believe the issue lies in the contents of the Dockerfile used to build the java image
The FROM statement is using an x86 docker image
if you manually pull down openjdk:8 and try and run it on z it should fail
i am not sure why they don't use the hyperledger/fabric-baseimage in the FROM statement
and then just install openjdk using apt-get
This is the Docker file used to build the javaenv Docker image...

FROM openjdk:8
RUN wget <https://services.gradle.org/distributions/gradle-2.12-bin.zip> -P /tmp --quiet
RUN unzip -q /tmp/gradle-2.12-bin.zip -d /opt && rm /tmp/gradle-2.12-bin.zip
RUN ln -s /opt/gradle-2.12/bin/gradle /usr/bin
ADD javashimsrc.tar.bz2 /root
ADD protos.tar.bz2 /root
WORKDIR /root
# Build java shim after copying proto files from fabric/proto
RUN core/chaincode/shim/java/javabuild.sh
from /src/github.com/hyperledger/fabric/images/javaenv
<http://Dockerfile.in|Dockerfile.in>
Yes. That way we won’t have dependency on any external (outside hyperledger) docker image
<@U0UHG4VP1> problems with Jira and Gerrit?
nginx down again?
<@U0KM61BCP> they look like they’re up to me, I’ll ask if there was an outage
what was that link again?
I forgot to bookmark and history archived
which link? the open a helpdesk ticket link?

<@U11NUTP4L> <@U0KPFAZNF> i was able to get the make process build the hyperledger/fabric-javaenv  docker image for z Systems by updating fabric/images/javaenv/Dockerfile.in.  i removed the FROM statement and added the following two statements:
FROM hyperledger/fabric-baseimage
RUN apt-get install -y openjdk-8-jdk

However... the javabuild.sh script fails with the following messages:
An exception occurred applying plugin request [id: 'java']
> Failed to apply plugin [id 'osdetector']
   > Could not create an instance of type com.google.gradle.osdetector.OsDetectorExtension_Decorated.

I dug into this some more and was able to turn on debug for the gradle build and just as I suspected, this version of gradle does not support the s390x platform.

Gradle build debug messages:
1:21:50.305 [ERROR] [org.gradle.BuildExceptionReporter]        ... 73 more
21:21:50.306 [ERROR] [org.gradle.BuildExceptionReporter] Caused by: kr.motd.maven.os.DetectionException: unknown os.arch: s390x
21:21:50.306 [ERROR] [org.gradle.BuildExceptionReporter]        at kr.motd.maven.os.Detector.detect(Detector.java:54)
21:21:50.307 [ERROR] [org.gradle.BuildExceptionReporter]        at com.google.gradle.osdetector.OsDetector$Impl.<init>(OsDetector.java:55)
21:21:50.308 [ERROR] [org.gradle.BuildExceptionReporter]        at com.google.gradle.osdetector.OsDetector.<clinit>(OsDetector.java:27)

If I comment out the javabuild.sh RUN step in the javaenv docker image build Dockerfile, the rest of the make build process completed without error on the s390x platform.  So I think the openjdk x86 docker image being used as a base for the build of the javaenv docker image along with gradle not supporting the s390x platform are the current issues with building 0.6 on the s390x platform.
<@U0YJUECE8|silliman> has joined the channel
<@U0UHG4VP1> any chance to see if vagrant was viable within the jenkins env?
<@U0KPFAZNF> I was able to install it, but I didn’t create any new instances
cool, let me know asap
what is the minimal test I need to do to prove or disprove if it works well enough?
run this: vagrant init ubuntu/trusty64; vagrant up --provider virtualbox
(in a empty dir)
note that it will create files such as Vagrantfile whereever you run it
if all goes well, it will succeed after setting up the basics
but I think you will know right away if basic things like VMX arent sufficiently available
ok
if it looks happy, you should also be able to “vagrant ssh” from that same dir

text: Awesome!
This means the packer job is likely to work
it did take forever to download from hashicorp though
Is this the same environment on all workers?
we should probably make a new image to support this
Yeah, the build will take even longer
I don't expect this to be a frequent task
like, bake in this stuff that will be fairly static
Exactly
right now we only have one type of build VM, so yes, it will be the same for all of them.
To date, I think we released .7 - .10 since YTD
So once every 2 months or so
do you think it would be worth the commonality of having vagrant baked into any build image?
I suspect the frequency will up tick slightly on account of it will be less painful to do now
I’d need to add vagrant 1.8.5 and however I would cache this ubuntu image, I was getting like 200k/s downloading it
I'll leave that up to you but caching of some form makes sense to me
Note that the packer build uses an ISO rather than a vagrant base though
OK. is this something we should trigger manually?
But same concept can apply:  you could put a squid proxy in front
The plan is to break out a different repo
Like Hyperledger/fabric-baseimage
if this is something I’d do every couple of months I’ll probably just eat the download cost in time
oh OK.
The we can trigger on commit
OK. what do you need from me?
I mean, repos are cheap, if you’re blocked on the new repo and the TSC approves I can make it quickly

attachments.title: ghaskins/hyperledger-fabric-baseimage
attachments.text: hyperledger-fabric-baseimage - Prototype for breaking out the baseimage from hyperledger fabric

text: the plan for that repo is to converge the stuff in fabric.git/image/base and fabric.git/devenv in a meaningful way such that we can turn that into the input stage to a CI pipeline to spit out the vagrant/dockerhub baseimages
if that looks good, we will propose the migration of that repo to something under hyperledger (presumably hyperledger/fabric-baseimage)
what we could use help on is perhaps the jenkins side of the equation
i could add you to that project, if you approve, such that you can help us get the proper webhooks in place, and then also help set up a jenkins project to accept it
for now, we could probably ignore the webhooks though and just work on the jenkins configuration
my thought is this is all sandbox type stuff, so I wasnt going to bother the TSC until we prove its workable
<@U0KM61BCP> any guidance on this?
ghaskins: I assume we can recover the previous settings for when we had Jenkins firing off against github, and set up a new project
